newsitem.title: PERU: Fujimori blames police, officials for Peru crisis.
newsitem.headline: Fujimori blames police, officials for Peru crisis.

text.p: President Alberto Fujimori blamed police and "some officials" for failing to prevent Peru's 70-day hostage siege as Marxist rebels and government negotiators prepared for new face-to-face talks on Tuesday to end the crisis.

"We cannot speak about culpability yet. There is no trial," Fujimori told reporters on Monday on a trip to Peru's eastern jungle. "But there is responsibility on the part of some officials and of members of the National Police."
An investigation was underway and published reports said some authorities may be punished.

Fujimori said Peru's intelligence service informed police in the Huancayo region and Lima that Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA) rebels had slipped weapons and fighters into the capital for a hostage-taking operation.
Police high command ordered "corrective measures" on Nov. 15 but, "apparently, adequate measures were not taken to assure that the reception at the Japanese embassy take place normally," he added.

His comments confirmed a secret intelligence report obtained by Reuters that showed regional anti-terrorist police warned authorities in Lima weeks before the takeover that the MRTA was planning an assault around Nov. 30.
On Dec. 17, rebels seized the diplomatic compound and took hundreds of hostages. All but 72 have been released.
Fujimori spoke on Monday after a fifth round of talks and the second meeting between government negotiator Domingo Palermo and MRTA chief Nestor Cerpa.

A statement issued by guarantors overseeing the talks merely said the two met in a "cordial atmosphere" and broached "important issues". The statement added that a sixth round of negotiations would be held on Tuesday.
Speaking in the jungle town of Mazamari, Fujimori said talks were in a "preliminary stage" and the two sides had not reached "a base agreement" for formal negotiations to end the crisis.

He denied a report in a Japanese newspaper that he had agreed to place on the agenda for final negotiations the rebels' main demand of freedom for 400 jailed comrades. The government flatly rejected the idea.
"That is not true," Fujimori said of the report in Mainichi Shimbun. "The government's position is the same."

Cerpa and his deputy, Rolly Rojas, were driven back to the besieged Japanese ambassador's residence in a Red Cross car from a safe house across the street after Monday's meeting, which lasted more than two hours.

When they left the diplomatic compound earlier in the morning, their fellow rebels cheered, broadcast a revolutionary anthem commemorating dead comrades and bellowed defiant slogans. "We are the ones who have taken the Japanese residence. Until death, damn it!" they shouted.
Talks began on Feb. 11 after weeks of intransigence over the rebels' central demand for the release of jailed comrades.
Argentine human rights group Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo were rebuffed again on Monday in their bid to play a role in resolving the hostage crisis.

A Mothers delegation was turned away at Government Palace when they tried for a second time to meet with Fujimori and were barred from visiting a women's prison as well as paying a visit to the hostages.
